nearbyspot.description: Dhom Dam is an earthfill and gravity dam on Krishna River near Wai in state of Maharashtra in India. In old times, it was known as Virat Nagari. Dhom is known in Maharashtra for its ghats on the banks of the Krishna River and its temples, including especially the "Shree Narsinha" temple on the "Kreeshna Ghat".Near Dhom Dam, the Sahyadri Boat Club offers many outdoor activities including motorboat rides, speedboating, water scooters and banana boat rides along with horse riding.
nearbyspot.essential: Wear comfortable pair of shoes;best visited during daylight hours;keep an extra pair pf clothing;bring water and food
nearbyspot.story: The construction of the Dhom Dam started in 1976. It was created to supply water for agriculture, for industries, and to supply drinking water for Wai, Panchgani-Mahabaleshwar and the surrounding villages on the bank of the dam. The Dhom Dam also supplied water for agriculture for Wai, Koregaon, Satara, Javli and Khandala talukas.The Dhom dam stands 50 feet tall from the lowest foundation and runs a length of 2,478 m.

nearbyspot.description: The Pratapgarh Fort is a historical monument that welcomes all the people interested in knowing everything about the history of the fort.The fort is situated 24 kilometres from the Mahabaleshwar hill station.The Pratapgarh is categorized into 2 parts – the upper fort and the lower part.The Pratapgarh Fort features the Mahadev Temple and Bhavani Temple along with a watchtower that is situated at its main entrance. Here you can also find a 17-feet tall statue of Shivaji Maharaj in its full glory.
nearbyspot.essential: Carry food and water;best visited during daylight hours;wear comfortable pair of shoes
nearbyspot.story: The historical significance of Pratapgad Fort lies in the Battle of Pratapgad, fought on 10 November 1659 between Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Afzal Khan, a general of the Bijapur Sultanate. This battle marked the first major test of the fledgling Maratha army and laid the foundation for the establishment of the Maratha Empire. The fort itself is strategically built atop a hill, approximately 1,080 meters above sea level, offering commanding views of the surrounding landscape.

nearbyspot.description: The highest point of Panchgani, Tableland is a popular sightseeing place in Mahabaleshwa.Visit One Tree Hill Point to enjoy a 360-degree view of the surrounding areas encompassed by stretching forests and deep valleys. Famous for trekking.The Pandava Footsteps is another attraction that catches everyone’s attention here at this location. It is said that there are actual footsteps of the Pandavas.Try your hand at horse riding to explore the best of the area. For your enjoyment, there are a range of arcade games available along with short prop games to bring the inner child out.
nearbyspot.essential: Wear comfortable pair of shoes ;best visited during daylight hours;prefer warm clothes in winters;Beaware of horse riding scams
nearbyspot.story: Table Land in Panchgani is a flat, expansive plateau, recognized as the second-largest in Asia. It's a popular tourist destination offering scenic views, recreational activities, and a tranquil atmosphere. Situated in Panchgani, Maharashtra, it's accessible by road and trekking paths, making it a favored spot for nature lovers and adventure seekers.

nearbyspot.description: Wai is a town in Satara district of Maharashtra state in India. Located on the Krishna River, Wai was a prominent town during the Peshwa era.Wai is a major city on the way to the hill stations of Mahabaleshwar and Panchgani.Wai taluka has seven ghats on the Krishna's banks: Gangapuri, Madhi Aali, Ganpati Aali, Dharmapuri, Brahmanshahi, Ramdoh Aali and Bhimkund Aali.Krishnamai Utsav is the main festival in Wai.A 105-year-old Govardhan Sanstha (Goshala) celebrates Shri Krishna Janma Ashtami (Gokul Ashtami). The two-day Jatra festival attracts people from all over Maharashtra. The annual fairs, Yatras/Jatras, began with the Yatra of Mahalaxmi of Bhuinj, Jamb, Kikli and Belmachi on Dassraa. Yatras in the Wai taluka include Mandhardevi, Bagad of Bavdhan, Kavathe, Kalambhe and Surur.
nearbyspot.essential: Modest dress codes;refrain from any alcohol;remove shoes at temples;follow local guidelines during rituals and while bathing at ghats
nearbyspot.story: Wai is located approximately 35 km north of the city of Satara.Wai was a prominent town during the Peshwa era. Two important Marathi Brahmin from ruling families had their origins here: Rani Lakshmibai of Jhansi (Tambe family) and Gopikabai, wife of Nanasaheb Peshwa (Raste family).Temples built in the Wai area tend to be built in Hemādpanti-style architecture. Use of huge stone slabs is the major characteristic of Hemādpanti architecture.

nearbyspot.description: This is a popular picnic spot with views of the Sahyadri range, Krishna Valley and waters of Dhom Dam. There is also a play area and food vendors.Trailhead for this particular trail lies by the Panchgani Mahabaleshwar Road, which can be reached via different modes of transport such as buses, taxis, cabs, or even private vehicles.Tourists from all walks of life love visiting Parsi Point at least once. Not only does this place have a wide range of things to keep your kids occupied all the time but it is also equipped with a plethora of stalls offering delicious snacks and beverages to satisfy everyone’s appetite.
nearbyspot.essential: Wear comfortable pair of shoes ;best visited during daylight hours;prefer warm clothes in winters;do not climbabove the fence
nearbyspot.story: If you’re on your Mahabaleshwar tour and looking for a place where you can breathe in the fresh air with lush green mountains all around the area, then you should look nowhere else than Parsi Point. Located on the way to Mahabaleshwar, Parsi Point is a renowned viewpoint in India that invites you to tuck your soul free in tranquility and attain peace of mind, away from the everyday stress of city life.Named after the Parsi community, the Parsi Point offers a perfect weekend getaway retreat to all nature-buffs, wanderers, and sightseeing lovers.

nearbyspot.description: The Sajjangad fort is located in the mountainous terrain of the Western Ghats. Being best known as a pilgrimage site, it is one of the protected monuments in West India. This beautiful fort is situated at about 16 kms from the city of Satara.The fort covers a vast area of the hill. Being constructed majorly by stone, it comprises of a set of 100 stairs to reach the main door.The sightseeing at this fort also includes few lakes, a temple devoted to Lord Ram and Lord Hanuman, another temple dedicated to Anglai Devi.
nearbyspot.essential: Wear Comfortable shoes;carry food and water;best visited in daylight hours;remove shoes at temple
nearbyspot.story: Sajjangad Fort was built by the Bahamani Emperors between 13th and 15th century AD. The fort is also known as Asvalayana Rishi’, named after the Rishi who used to live there for an abundant period. It was also called ‘Aswalya gad’ because of the number of bears strolling around. The name of the fort means ‘Fort of good people’. This particular fort is also known as the spiritual centre of King Shivaji.The Bahmani Kingdoms constructed the fort between (1347-1527), after which the Mughals conquered the fort. Later it was won by Shivaji’s Army in 1663.

nearbyspot.description: Panchgani is famous for its strawberries, scenic beauty, and colonial-era charm. It's a popular hill station nestled in the Sahyadri mountain range known for its pleasant climate, strawberry farms, and attractions like Table Land and Sydney Point.The temperature in Panchgani is around 12 degrees Celsius during winter, and sometimes reaches 34 degrees Celsius during summer.
nearbyspot.essential: Wear warm clothes in winters;Try wearning comfortable clothes as some areas contains treks;Beware of tourists traps;leave early for the best experience
nearbyspot.story: Panchgani was developed by the British during the British Raj as a summer resort under the supervision of Lord John Chesson in the 1860s.Panchgani was developed as a retirement place because its climate remained pleasant throughout the year.The place was aptly named Panchgani, meaning "land between five villages".Panchgani is nestled in the middle of five hills in the Western Ghats alias Sahyādri mountain ranges.

nearbyspot.description: Satara is a city located in the Satara District of Maharashtra state of India, near the confluence of the river Krishna and its tributary, the Venna.Satara lies on the slope of Ajinkyatara fort. It lies on the western side of the Deccan Plateau.Satara is famous for the Kaas Pathar, Thoseghar, and a lot of natural sites present in the vicinity of the city. Kass Plateau has been awarded as a UNESCO's World Heritage Site (WHS).The famous tourist points near Satara city are Ajinkyatara Fort ,Jarandeshwar Hanuman,Sajjangad Fort Kaas Plateau,Baramotichi Vihir ,Thoseghar Waterfall.Yewateshwa,Bamnoli,Dhom Dam,Raje Baksavar Peer Saaheb Dargha ,Chaphal.
nearbyspot.essential: Wear comfortable pair of shows;best visited in daylight hours;remove shoes at temple;follow local rituals
nearbyspot.story: The city was established in the 16th century and was the seat of the Chhatrapati of the Maratha Kingdom, Shahu I.The city gets its name from the seven forts (Sat-Tara) which are around the city. The city is known as a Soldier's city as well as Pensioner's city.The first known Muslim rule of the Deccan took place in 1296. In 1636, the Nizam Shahi dynasty came to an end. In 1663, Shivaji conquered Parali and Satara fort. Satara was the first state to be annexed by British Governor-General Dalhousie’s policy of ‘Doctrine of Lapse’ in 1848.
